results.title: The Lucky years
results.creator_credit: Brian Luscombe and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Brian Luscombe enlisted in the Air Force on Australia Day 1942. He was 18 and wanted to be a pilot. Dubbed Lucky Luscombe, Brian talks about his years as a pilot in the RAAF in World War II.
results.description: Brian Luscombe enlisted in the Air Force on Australia Day 1942. He was 18 and wanted to be a pilot. Dubbed Lucky Luscombe, Brian talks about his years as a pilot in the RAAF in World War II.
description_for_label: Brian Luscombe enlisted in the Air Force on Australia Day 1942. He was 18 and wanted to be a pilot. Dubbed Lucky Luscombe, Brian talks about his years as a pilot in the RAAF in World War II.

results.title: The Ballad of Betty and Joe
results.brief_description:
Every morning Betty tramps alone through the big city to join her fellow buskers in the pedestrian tunnel below, trying to earn a living. But her earnings are meagre, and to make things worse, the new security guard, Joe, is trying to confiscate her fiddle. While Betty dreams of fame and fortune, Joe dreams of earplugs – something’s got to give!

Featuring Alice Ansara & Tony Barry
with Betty Lucas, Alec Morgan, Damian Rebgetz, Helen Thearle, Eden Falk
Composer: Jan Preston • Fiddle: Phil Hartl
Animation: Glenn Harrison
Supervising Editor: Nick Meyers •
Editors: Nick Meyers, Vanessa Milton, Kit Guyatt
Cinematography: Tom Cowan, Hugh Miller
Sound: William Lawlor, Finn O’Keefe, • Sound Mix: Sam Petty
Costumes: Clementine Hield • Make-up: Helen Evans
Producers: Martha Ansara, Charlie Carman, Rivka Hartman, Adam Rigby
Script: Rivka Hartman, Martha Ansara • Director: Martha Ansara
Source: Ballad Films website http://www.balladfilms.com.au/films/ballad-of-betty-joe/ [Last accessed 10/01/2023]

results.title: I Remember 1948
results.brief_description:
In Australia’s first bilingual Arabic/English film, four elders give eye-witness accounts of the tumultuous days of Al Nakba, the catastrophe, May 15th, 1948, and its aftermath. As children and young adults, they and their families were among 750,000 Palestinians fleeing for their lives, in the drive to enlarge the recently created State of Israel.

The stories told by these speakers are poignant, unexpected and sometimes surprising, expressing not only the tragedies but also the small miracles which occur in a human catastrophe of such dimensions. Prevented from returning to their homes, the speakers lived as refugees, eventually making their way to Australia. Their continued longing to see their homeland eloquently expresses the feelings of the dispossessed everywhere, and gives this film a universal dimension.

Source: Ballad Films website http://www.balladfilms.com.au/films/i-remember-1948/ [Last accessed 10/01/2023]

results.title: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [April 2010]
results.creator_credit: Bob Gatherum, Con Bell, Gordon White, Grant Coultman-Smith, Hugh Melville, Jack Holdsworth, John Vincent, Ralph Basson, Reginald Relf, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Nine Victorian war veterans tell of their service during various wars for Australia. Covering World War II and the Vietnam War, these men share their experiences, joys and traumas of this time that would shape the rest of their lives. Created as part of ‘In our words : stories from Victorian veterans’ Digital Storytelling project at ACMI.

results.title: The Dame Was Loaded for DOS
results.creator_credit: Beam Software and Philips Interactive Media, Inc.
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. Two CD-ROM, CD case insert and manual in 2 CD capacity jewel case
results.brief_description:
A hardboiled detective, femme Fatales, missing people and money. The Dame was Loaded has all the hardboiled elements of film noir and is just as cinematic.

Created using innovative Full Motion Video (FMV) technology, which was developed in-house at Beam Software, this point-and-click adventure incorporated real footage of actors that players interact with to solve the mystery. At the time when computer graphics were limited, PMV games tried to generate empathy in players by putting them in the protagonist’s point of view and presenting other characters as real people in a fully realised game world.

When it was made it was the largest multimedia production in Australia, with game developers collaborating closely with actors and film crews, who used iconic Melbourne landmarks as settings like the art-deco former police headquarters on Russell Street.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Beam Software and Philips Interactive Media, Inc.
